captions.text:
Slitterhead, as well as being very
concise instructions for a brain surgeon,

is a new Japanese horror game
that comes to us from the creator

of the original Silent Hill (ooh)
and the original Forbidden Siren
(slightly more divisive oooh).

And obviously, I needed
to check this out.

I&#39;m always down for a new survival
horror, that&#39;s why I&#39;ve been nailing

dead ferrets to the front
door of Bear Grylls&#39; house.
But now, having finished Slitterhead,

I’m not sure I can recommend it to
my fellow survival horror enthusiasts,

it containing very little
in the way of survival.
Or, ultimately, horror.
Making it a decisive new addition
to the &quot;...&quot; genre.
It is a very weird game,

and I like to think of myself
as a champion of the weird.

The weird has an important
place in the world.

A lot of people tell me
dead ferrets are weird,

and their place is the front door
of Bear Grylls&#39; house. Anyway.
The premise of Slitterhead

is that you are a bodiless spirit hovering
around in contemporary Hong Kong

who can&#39;t remember
where they came from or

why they&#39;re there, but they do
remember that they really hate

Slitterheads, which are a
race of sinister monsters

who possess the bodies of
humans and eat their brains.

So we have to counter them by
possessing the bodies of humans
and making them fight to the death.
It&#39;s cute when we do it.

Slitterhead&#39;s arrival will
probably cheer up

Messiah and Driver: San Francisco,
the only two previous noteworthy titles

in the criminally underweight
genre of &quot;possess &#39;em ups,&quot;

which I think has much untapped
potential as a core mechanic.

It&#39;d be great for avoiding cockup
cascades in a stealth game;

you get spotted by guards,
you just gleefully watch them

pound the clueless twat you used to be
from the safety of a nearby squirrel.
But the reason why

I omit &quot;survival&quot; from the &quot;survival
horror&quot; label is that &quot;survival&quot; to me

implies resource management,
and the only resource

you manage in Slitterhead
is the one thing planet Earth

will never be in shortage of:
slack-jawed, generic twats.

The core gameplay is melee
hack-and-slash combat, and initially,

I found it annoying: enemy
attacks send you flying,

so it&#39;s easy to get stunlocked;
there&#39;s this elaborate parry system

where you can deflect one incoming
attack, which is a fat lot of good
when there&#39;s four of the buggers

swinging their uncircumcised
foreskin-like heads around.
But the combat clicked when I realized

that if I&#39;m getting overwhelmed,
I just hop out of my current dude

and possess one on the other side
of the room...and shove an uneven

baseball bat made of frozen blood right
up my tormentor&#39;s unsettling phallic arse.

&quot;Duh, Yahtzee, the
tutorial flat-out tells you

that newly possessed guys have a buff,
and if you&#39;re not rapidly body switching,

you&#39;re playing it wrong.&quot;
Alright, so I&#39;m a slow learner.

Your mum never complains when
she&#39;s giving me cunnilingus lessons.

Shittertoilet successfully makes
the most of its core possession idea.

Generally, before you fight a
Slitterhead, you have to chase it down,

and it&#39;s very satisfying to watch them
sweatily sprint away at full pelt,

panting and whimpering and knocking
obstacles down in their wake,

not realizing you&#39;ve already possessed
someone around the next corner

and are poised to crack him
in the teeth with a stick.

Finally, video games have captured the
experience of being in a Droopy cartoon.

The other main thing you do is identify disguised
Slitterheads concealed as random citizenry,

and the game borrows Siren&#39;s iconic
sightjacking mechanic to help you do that,

but the samey environments
render it kinda pointless.
&quot;Oh, looks like the target

is standing in a dark, grimy alleyway,
talking to a smoking man in a vest.”

Do you have any idea how little
that narrows it down?.GIF

Fortunately, there&#39;s also
a dirty great visual effect

on the screen pointing
directly at the Slitterhead

so you don&#39;t need sightjacking at all,
turns out; feels like it&#39;s more here

as a nostalgic callback to
a no-longer-relevant era,

much like the concept of
American exceptionalism.

That aside, I guess I like
the core gameplay;

it evokes the unbridled creativity and
bold experimental spirit of the PS2 era.

Shame it brought everything
else from back then

with it as well: janky design
choices, weird dialogue system

that&#39;s only 1% voiced (and
all the rest of the time,

characters signal communication
by making weird, breathy,

and faintly erotic grunting sounds),
and everything looking like poo.
The game has a mission-based structure

where you alternate between
conversations with the main characters

that are little more than text dumps
in fancy hats and going to one of three

or four different vaguely
open-ended grimy urban levels

to do more of the same shit as always
(probably chase a dude, probably fight

one of those big praying mantis lads),
and it smacks of trying to stretch

as much runtime as possible
out of a very small toybox.

It fails as a horror game because
it&#39;s not the least bit scary.

I mean, it is gory, and obviously,
having your body taken over

and used against your will to undermine
humanity is conceptually horrifying,

but I&#39;d need to have some investment
in humanity for that to work,
and the humanity in this game

feels more akin to a fungus
or a form of precipitation.

Since there need to be randos
around for you to possess

for the core gameplay to work,
every time you enter combat,

some just mysteriously
spawn in around the arena.

You can be confronting the final boss
on a lonely midnight rooftop in the rain

and there&#39;ll still be four
or five gormless twats

milling about like the last few
gazelles who missed the stampede.

The story starts out with
a nice, straightforward

premise—Slitterheads bad people eat
brainy ooh scary nasty kill them all—then

introduces a time loop element to explain
why we keep having to repeat the missions

(still fine, I guess), but then
the plot feels increasingly

like a chicken pot pie got projectile
vomited at the ceiling fan.

Turns out, some Slitterheads are good
and are trying to coexist with humanity.

Oh wait, no they&#39;re not, they
were pretending. Wait, yes they are!

There&#39;s a good one right there.
Are we the bad guys now?

Let&#39;s go to a fucking parallel
universe and fight ourselves,

and then come back and do it again
but from the other side. Bored now.
Plane crash, everyone dies.

WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU ON
ABOUT, SLITTERHEAD?
The plot centers around Rarities,

specific characters with
special upgradeable superpowers

we can use while possessing
them and whom we bring along

on all our missions, and
there are several side ones

we can unlock from doing
certain optional objectives.

Except every now and again, the
plot stops dead, sits down,

sticks out its lower lip like
a little toddler, and goes,

&quot;I&#39;m not continuing until you find
all the optional characters.&quot;

WELL, THEY&#39;RE NOT FUCKING
OPTIONAL, THEN, ARE THEY?

And I wouldn&#39;t mind, but most
of these characters proceed

to have bugger all importance to the
plot. It&#39;s like if the Beatles held up

a songwriting session to
wait for Ringo to arrive.

This is exactly the kind of thing
Forbidden Siren did, actually,

which is a game some people
seemed to like, but of this

game&#39;s two spiritual predecessors,
THAT&#39;s the one you want to be closer to?

That&#39;s like turning down
a lovely slice of cake

in favor of rubbing your
cheek on a bathroom floor.
